metadata.title: Enhanced Catalytic Activity and Magnetic Properties of Spinel Mn xZn 1−xFe 2O4 (0.0 ≤x≤ 1.0) Nano-Photocatalysts by Microwave Irradiation Route

sections.text:
G. Padmapriya ppstminex@gmail.com
A. Manikandan mkavath15@gmail.com;manikandana.che@bharathuniv.ac.in
1 Department of Chemistry, Bharath Institute of Higher Education and Research, Bharath University, Chennai, 600 073, India
2 IJN-UTM Cardiovascular Engineering Centre, Faculty of Biosciences and Medical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Skudai 81310, Johor Malaysia
3 Post Graduate and Research Department of Chemistry, Presidency College, Chennai, 600 005, India
Mn2+ cation, due to the replacement of the non-magnetic nature of Zn2+ by the higher magnetic moment of Mn2+ in the ZnFe2O4 lattice and also the distribution of cations at tetrahedral (A) and octahedral (B) sites. Photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of methylene blue (MB) using spinel MnxZn1−xFe2O4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 1.0) nanocatalysts was carried out, and the PCD efficiency is increased with increasing Mn2+ ions, and the sample Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 showed better efficiency than other samples, due to their smaller particle size and higher surface area.
Keywords Spinel ferrites · Nanocrystals · X-ray diffraction · Dye degradation · Magnetic properties · Photocatalyst

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, nanostructured semiconductor materials are considered extraordinarily attractive, due to their superior physicochemical and magneto-optical properties [1, 2]. Among them, spinel-type nanomaterials have become an important area in an interdisciplinary area [3–5]. Spinel materials with the general formula of A2+(B3+)2O4 (where A2+ = Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, etc., and B3+ = Fe3+, Al3+) spinel oxides displayed a variety of applications. From the above materials, spinel ferrites with the formula of AFe2O4 (A = Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, etc.) exhibit remarkable electro-magnetic and catalytic/photocatalytic properties [6–8]. Nowadays, zinc ferrites (ZnFe2O4) have been extensively studied, due to their interesting properties such as chemical reactivity, stability,
photoactivity, and also being magnetically separable and reusable by applying an external magnetic field [9, 10].
ZnFe2O4 is a normal spinel; Zn2+ ions are occupied tetrahedral (A) sites, while Fe3+ ions are occupied octahedral (B) sites coordinated by oxygen atoms [10]. It is well known that the spinel ferrite allows the introduction of different metal ions and changes their structural, morphological, optical, magnetic and catalytic properties considerably. Also metal doping in the spinel lattice enhanced the catalytic/ photocatalytic properties. Manikandan et al. [11–15] reported metal doped oxides/sulfides and observed enhanced catalytic/photocatalytic activity.
Various methods such as hydrothermal, ball milling, co-precipitation, sol-gel [15–20], etc. have been used for the preparation of spinel magnetic materials with different morphologies. However, the above strategy encountered several drawbacks such as the requirement of complicated equipment, long preparation time, and the need of higher temperature. Kulal et al. [21] synthesized Dy-doped spinel Co-Zn ferrite nanoparticles by sol-gel method and further calcinations at 950 ◦C for 6 hrs and found the particle sizes in the range of 30–40 nm. Recently, combustion methods have gained fascination and considerable interest in metal oxide ceramic materials, due to the requirement of inexpensive precursors and short preparation time. Costa et al. [22] reported Zn-doped NiFe2O4 nanoparticles by combustion method and observed enhanced structural and magnetic properties. Sertkol et al. [23] and Koseoglu et al. [24] synthesized Ni-Zn and Co-Zn ferrites by microwave combustion method and reported structural and morphological properties. Kambale et al. [25] reported Ni-Zn ferrite nanoparticles by combustion method and studied electromagnetic properties. Alarifi et al. [26] reported spinel NiFe2O4 nanoparticles by combustion method and observed enhanced structural and magnetic properties. In this method, metal nitrates act as cation sources, while organic fuels such as glycine, urea, citric acid, sucrose, hydrazine, and alanine act as reducing agents.
Recently, spinel ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles have been widely considered by worldwide researchers, because of their trendy size-dependent magneto-optical and catalytic properties as compared to their same bulk materials. Spinel ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles (band gap energy, 1.9 eV) have gained significant interest in photocatalysts, due to their photochemical stability, low cost, and visible-light response [27–29]. Photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of methylene blue (MB) has been investigated for different concentrations of the Mn2+-doped ZnFe2O4 catalyst, and the observed photocatalytic activity is correlated with the physicochemical properties. Therefore, it is highly interesting and desirable to study the photocatalytic activity of MnxZn1−xFe2O4 nanoparticles.
In this present study, Mn-doped ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles were uniformly distributed by microwave combustion method without any additional calcination steps. The addition of Mn2+ cations in the spinel ZnFe2O4 lattice influenced their particle size, lattice constant, magnetization, and PCD efficiency. Therefore, the objectives of this study were to examine the effect of Mn-doped ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles by microwave combustion method and to evaluate their structural, morphological, magnetic and photocatalytic properties.

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials and Methods
sections.text: All the chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade, obtained from Merck, India, and used as received without further purification. Zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 98 %), ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 98 %), and manganese nitrate (Mn(NO3)2·4H2O) were used as precursors, and glycine was used as the fuel for this method. The compositions were prepared with the addition of manganese by different molar ratios (MnxZn1−xFe2O4 with x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) to ZnFe2O4. For the preparation of undoped and Mn-doped ZnFe2O4 using the microwave combustion technique, the precursor mixture in glycine was placed into a domestic microwave oven and exposed to the microwave energy in a 2.45- GHz multimode cavity at 850 W for 10 min. After the completion of the reaction, the solid powder was obtained and then it was washed with ethanol and dried at 75 ◦C for 1 h. The obtained powders were labeled as ZnFe2O4, Mn0.2Zn0.8Fe2O4, Mn0.4Zn0.6Fe2O4, Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, Mn0.8Zn0.2Fe2O4, and MnFe2O4, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2 Characterization Techniques
sections.text:
The structural characterization of spinel MnxZn1−xFe2O4 (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) nanoparticles was performed using a Rigaku Ultima X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Structural refinements using the Rietveld method were carried out by PDXL program; both refined lattice parameters and crystallite size of the obtained ferrites were reported. The surface functional groups were analyzed by Perkin Elmer FT-IR spectrometer. Morphological studies and energy-dispersive X-ray analysis of pure and Mn-doped ZnFe2O4 nanocrystals have been performed with a Jeol JSM6360 high-resolution scanning electron microscope. The transmission electron micrographs were carried out by Philips-TEM (CM20). The surface area was derived from the N2 adsorption-desorption
isotherms using liquid nitrogen at 77 K using an automatic adsorption instrument (Quantachrome Corp. Nova-1000 gas sorption analyzer). Magnetic measurements were carried out at room temperature using a PMC MicroMag 3900 model vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) equipped with a 1-T magnet.

sections.heading: 2.3 Photocatalytic Degradation Procedure
sections.text:
All photochemical reactions under identical conditions were carried out in a self-designed photocatalytic reactor. This model consists of eight mediumpressure mercury vapor lamps (8 W) set in parallel and emitting a 365 nm wavelength. It has a reaction chamber with specially designed
reflectors made of highly polished aluminum and builtin cooling fan at the bottom and black cover to prevent UV leakage. It is provided with the magnetic stirrer at the center. An open borosilicate glass tube of 40 cm height and 12.6 mm diameter was used as a reaction vessel. The irradiation was carried out using only six parallel medium pressure mercury lamps. The solution was aerated continuously by a pump to provide oxygen and for the complete mixing of the solution. Prior to photocatalytic experiments, the adsorption of MB on pure ZnFe2O4 and Mn-doped ZnFe2O4 nanophotocatalyst was carried out by mixing 100 mL of aqueous solution of MB with a fixed weight of the respective photocatalyst.

sections.heading: 3.1 Powder XRD Analysis
sections.text:
The purity and structural phase of the samples were confirmed by analyzing the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns. Figure 1(a–f) shows the XRD patterns of spinel MnxZn1−xFe2O4 prepared with different concentrations of Mn2+ ions (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0). The main diffraction peaks (2θ) appear at about 29.98◦, 35.71◦, 36.25◦, 42.35◦, 53.27◦, 57.27◦, 62.36◦, and 74.24◦, which are attributed to the (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511), (440), and (533) planes, respectively, showing the characteristics of a single-phase cubic spinel structure of ZnFe2O4 (JCPDS card no. 22-1012) [30] and MnFe2O4 (JCPDS card no. 74-2403) [31], respectively. The average crystallite size was calculated from the diffraction peak of the (311) plane in the XRD profile, in accordance with the Debye-Scherrer formula:
D = 0.89λ β cos θ
where D is the average crystallite size; λ, the X-ray wavelength (0.1542 nm); β, the full width at half maximum (FW-HM); and θ , the Bragg angle of the (311) plane. Average crystallite sizes of the samples are summarized in Table 1. It has been observed that the crystallite size is decreased from 21.15 to 15.48 nm with an increase in Mn content, up to x = 0.0–0.6. However, with a further increase in the Mn content (x = 1.0), the crystallite size is increased to 19.26 nm. It has a minimum crystallite size of 15.48 nm for x = 0.6 Mn content (Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4).
Powder XRD data is fitted using the Rietveld refinement XRD analysis of the Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 sample as
given in Fig. 2. Rietveld refinement XRD was designed to refine simultaneously both the lattice parameter and crystallite size, and the observed values are listed in Table 1 (Fig. 3). From the results, it was observed that lattice parameter values increased from 8.443 Å (ZnFe2O4) to 8.472 Å (MnFe2O4) with an increase in the Mn dopant. It is mainly due to the replacement of a smaller ionic radius of Zn2+ (0.83 Å) ions in the ZnFe2O4 spinel by a larger ionic radius of Mn2+ (0.92 Å) ions [32–36].

sections.heading: 3.2 FT-IR Analysis
sections.text: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was used to analyze the formation of functional groups. Figure 4 shows the FT-IR spectral analysis of spinel MnxZn1−xFe2O4 (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) nanoparticles. Two major sweeping metal-oxygen (M-O) peaks are seen in the FT-IR spectra in the range of 900 to 450 cm−1, which established the spinel ferrites. The greatest one is commonly observed in the range 600–500 cm−1 equivalent to fundamental stretching vibrations of the metal oxide at the A site, Mtetra ↔O, while the lowest peak, frequently observed in the range of 450–400 cm−1, is assigned to B site metal stretching, Mocta ↔O [37]. The wide peaks observed at ∼3450 and ∼1630 cm−1 demonstrate the amount of adsorbed water on the surface.

sections.heading: 3.3 SEM Studies
sections.text:
High-resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM) was used to analyze the surface morphology of the samples. Figure 5a shows the HR-SEM image of the Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 sample, indicating homogeneous spherical shaped particle-like nanocrystal formation below 25 nm in
size and the particles are agglomerated together, due to the presence of magnetic interactions among them.
Sample purity and elemental composition of the samples were recorded at room temperature by energy-dispersive Xray (EDX) analysis. Figure 5b shows the EDX spectra of the Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 sample, consisting of Fe, Zn, Mn, and O peaks, which confirmed that the prepared samples are pure and there is no other impurity. A small peak appeared at 2.1 keV for all the samples, which indicates the occurrence of Au, which has been used as a sputter coating for HR-SEM analysis for the better visibility of the surface morphology.

sections.heading: 3.4 HR-TEM Analysis
sections.text:
Figure 6a shows the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) image of the Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 sample, which consists of nanocrystalline spherical-shaped particles, which are in good agreement and evidence of the HR-SEM images. Also, the particle sizes of the sample ranged from 12 to 16 nm. Average crystallite sizes, obtained from powder XRD and Rietveld refinement XRD analysis, are consistent with particle sizes calculated from HR-TEM images. Figure 6b shows the SAED patterns of the
Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 sample, which confirmed well crystalline nature of the final product.

sections.heading: 3.5 Magnetic Measurements
sections.text:
A vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM measurements) has been used to analyze the magnetic characterizations of the samples. The observed magnetic hysteresis (M-H) loops of MnxZn1−xFe2O4 (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) samples are shown in Fig. 7. From the VSM measurements, saturation magnetization (Ms), remanent magnetization (Mr), and coercivity (Hc) values are evaluated and the values are summarized in Table 1. When non-magnetic Zn2+ in ZnFe2O4 is substituted by magnetic Mn2+ ions, there is a drastic change in magnetic properties such as Ms, Mr, and Hc.
M-H loops show a soft magnetic nature of the materials. ZnFe2O4, Mn0.2Zn0.8Fe2O4, and Mn0.4Zn0.6Fe2O4 samples show a superparamagnetic behavior, which is confirmed by the non-saturation observed in the M-H loop and also the absence of the hysteresis, whereas Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, Mn0.8Zn0.2Fe2O4, and MnFe2O4 samples indicate ferromagnetism. Spinel ZnFe2O4 is a soft magnetic material. However, the values of Ms increased with increasing concentration of Mn2+, due to the non-magnetic moment (0 μB) of Zn2+ ions replaced by the higher magnetic moment (5 μB) of Mn2+ ions in the ZnFe2O4 lattice [31, 32]. The Ms value of undoped ZnFe2O4 is 3.851 emu/g, and the values are increased up to 64.56 emu/g with increasing Mn dopant, and the sample MnFe2O4 shows a higher value (Fig. 8). It is evidently understood that the magnetic properties are affected by the composition, cation, and nature of the dopant [33–35].

sections.heading: 3.6 Photocatalytic Activity
sections.text:
It is generally known that the surface area, particle size, morphology, nature, and composition of doping metal ions are significant factors, which influence the catalytic activity. Mathubala et al. [37] reported that the photocatalytic activity of spinel ferrite nanoparticles noticeably relies on surface properties and surface defects, particle size, and morphology. In this present study, MnxZn1−xFe2O4 (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) nanocatalysts prepared by the microwave heating approach for the application of photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of methylene blue (MB) dye and the experiments were carried out under UV-Vis light at 365 nm in wavelength.
3.6.1 Effects of Mn Doping on the Photocatalytic Activity of ZnFe2O4 Nanoparticles
The effect of Mn doping on ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles for the photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of MB was evaluated (Fig. 9). The PCD efficiency of MB is very low when using an undoped ZnFe2O4 nanocatalyst, and it was enhanced by increasing the Mn dopant and showed a maximum PCD activity for the sample Mn0.6Mn0.4Fe2O4 (x = 0.6), which may be due to the higher surface area to volume ratio and smaller particle size of Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanoparticles. Nevertheless, excessive dopants of Mn dopant (x = 0.8 and 1.0) in the spinel ZnFe2O4 lattice can retard the photocatalytic activity, due to the higher particle size and lower surface area of the samples, which results in the decrease of PCD efficiency. Moreover, the sample Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 shows maximum photocatalytic activity of MB degradation in an obvious increase in Mn dopant. However, our present study confirms that the PCD efficiency of the spinel ZnFe2O4 sample was improved by the addition of Mn content.

sections.heading: 3.6.2 Effect of Surface Area on the Photocatalytic Activity of MnxZn1−xFe2O4 Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Nanomaterials have a higher specific surface area, which hopefully has an effect on the catalytic activity in photocatalysis. Surface areas of ZnFe2O4, Mn0.2Zn0.8Fe2O4, Mn0.4Zn0.6Fe2O4, Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, Mn0.8Zn0.2Fe2O4, and MnFe2O4 nanoparticles are 27.65, 29.79, 34.78, 41.56 40.73 and 39.58 m2/g, respectively (Fig. 9) The surface area is improved with increasing Mn content up to x = 0.6, and the sample Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 has a higher surface area (41.56 m2/g) than other samples (Table 1). Moreover, the decrease of particle size increased the surface area and the results are in good agreement with the average crystallite size calculated by powder XRD analysis. It is well known that, when the particle size decreased, the surface area
increased significantly, and the particle dispersion amounts also increased in solution, which enhanced the photon absorbance, which leads to the recovery of their catalytic activity [38, 39]. It is understood that an increase of the surface area increased the number of active sites in the catalytic surface, which enhanced the photocatalytic activity. However, the higher surface area of spinel Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanoparticles showed better photocatalytic activity than other samples.

sections.heading: 3.6.3 Effect of the Catalyst Dosage on the Photocatalytic Degradation of Methylene Blue Dye
sections.text:
A blank experiment without any catalyst was carried out to examine the amount of degradation (photolysis) efficiency of MB, and no evidence of PCD of MB in aqueous solution was observed. When the Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanocatalyst is present in aqueous solution, the PCD of MB was observed under irradiation of UV light. Also, the PCD efficiency of MB was found to be increased with an increasing amount of the Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanocatalyst up to
30 mg/100 mL. However, a further increase of the amount of the spinel Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 catalyst showed a negative effect (Fig. 10). Nevertheless, an excessive amount of
the Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 catalyst can retard the photocatalytic activity, due to the excess amounts deposited on the surface, which results in the decrease of PCD efficiency. The increase in the amount of nanocatalyst increased the active sites on the catalyst surface, which in turn increased the amount of ·OH (hydroxyl) and ·O−2 (superoxide) radicals and degraded the MB dye [40, 41]. Also, the addition of an excess amount of catalyst beyond the optimum may answer the agglomeration of catalyst particles and formed turbidity, which results in lower photon absorption, and thereby, PCD efficiency was decreased.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
Spinel MnxZn1−xFe2O4 (x = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) nanoparticles have been successfully prepared by microwave irradiation route using glycine as the fuel. Powder XRD, FT-IR, EDX, and SAED results confirmed the formation of pure cubic-phase spinel-type MnxZn1−xFe2O4 structure with well-crystalline nature. The average crystallite size was calculated by Sherrer’s formula and observed in the range from 21.15 to 15.48 nm. HR-SEM and HR-TEM images showed the nanoparticles like morphology of the samples with slight agglomeration. VSM analysis showed that the magnetization values are increased with increasing Mn2+ cation, due to the reorganization of divalent cations at tetrahedral and octahedral sites. At lower Mn concentration (x = 0.0, 0.2, and 0.4), the samples showed a superparamagnetic behavior, whereas at higher concentration (x = 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0), they showed ferromagnetic behavior. Photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of textile dye (methylene blue) using the MnxZn1−xFe2O4 spinel nanocatalysts was carried
out, and the sample Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 showed good PCD efficiency than other samples, due to their smaller particle size and higher surface area. PCD of MB azo dye was carried out and better results were observed than the reported results.

metadata.abstractText: Spinel MnxZn1−xFe2O4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 1.0) nanocatalysts were successfully prepared by simple onepot microwave combustion method using glycine as the fuel. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectral results confirmed the formation of pure-phase cubic spinel structured products. Average crystallite sizes of the samples were calculated using Sherrer’s formula, and the range from 21.15 to 15.48 nm. Spherical-shaped particles like nanostructured morphology were confirmed by high-resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) analyses. Magnetic characterization of the samples was measured by vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM), and it was observed that the magnetization values increased with increasing G. Photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of methylene blue (MB) using spinel MnxZn1−xFe2O4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 1.0) nanocatalysts was carried out, and the PCD efficiency is increased with increasing Mn2+ ions, and the sample Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 showed better efficiency than other samples, due to their smaller particle size and higher surface area.
